Laboratory of Advanced Materials and Catalytic Engineering, Dalian University of Technology Dalian 116024 China As a carbon-free hydrogen carrier, ammonia requires efficient decomposition catalysts to enable its practical use in hydrogen energy applications. In this study, a series of Ce1-yLayOx oxides with varying La/Ce molar ratios were synthesized via a citric acid method and utilized as supports for Ni-based NH3 decomposition catalysts. The La/Ce molar ratio significantly influenced the catalytic performance, with Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox exhibiting the highest catalytic activity, achieving nearly 100 % ammonia conversion at 540 ℃ (GHSV= 9000 mL gcat −1 h−1) and 600 ℃ (GHSV = 30000 mL gcat −1 h−1). Various characterizations demonstrated that optimal La/Ce ratio promoted uniform dispersion of Ni nanoparticles (4.6 nm), maximizing available active sites for NH3 adsorption. Moreover, the Ce0.5La0.5Ox support enriched the catalyst surface with high Ce3+ species and oxygen vacancies, facilitating electron transfer to Ni species. These electron-enriched Ni species significantly enhanced the cleavage of Ni-N bonds and facilitated the recombination of N adatoms, thereby boosting the overall reaction rate. This work provided fundamental insights into the critical role of metal-support electron transfer in optimizing catalytic performance for efficient ammonia decomposition, offering valuable guidance for the design of advanced hydrogen production catalysts. Graphical Abstract Keywords Ammonia decomposition Ce1-yLayOx Ni-based catalyst Reaction mechanism Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The rapid global population growth and excessive dependence of fossil fuel have resulted in serious climate change and energy shortages, exacerbating economic and geopolitical instability. Consequently, advancing green, renewable, and clean energy technologies has become an urgent global priority for sustainable development [1,2]. Hydrogen, with its high energy density and carbon-free combustion, is regarded as one of the most promising sustainable energies [3]. However, the widespread adoption of hydrogen energy faces substantial challenges, particularly in storage and transportation, owing its low volumetric energy density and inherent safety concerns [4]. To overcome these limitations, research has focused on developing efficient hydrogen production techniques and the identification of practical chemical hydrogen storage carriers for on-site generation [5]. Ammonia (NH3) has garnered significant attention as a leading candidate for hydrogen storage due to its exceptional properties [5,6]. Notably ammonia decomposition produces only N2 and H2, ensuring straightforward separation and purification processes [7]. Additionally, liquid ammonia exhibits exceptional energy density and the highest volumetric hydrogen density among known carriers, enabling safer and more efficient transportation [8,9]. Owing to these advantages, ammonia has become a highly favorable candidate for hydrogen storage, attracting widespread interest in sustainable energy research [7]. The on-site production of hydrogen via ammonia decomposition has garnered extensive industrial application. Currently, nickel-based catalysts supported on Al2O3 are widely employed in industrial cracking units operating at temperatures between 850 and 950 °C, primarily for applications in metal annealing and galvanizing processes [7]. Additionally, ammonia decomposition has become well-established in the field of fuel cells. For example, in Denmark, Rencat has commercialized a technology that product low-cost, high-purity hydrogen from ammonia for fuel cell systems. Furthermore, hydrogen obtained through ammonia cracking can be utilized as a fuel for internal combustion engines. A prototype vehicle operating on a blend of NH3 and H2 was demonstrated in 2013, with hydrogen supplied from an on-board catalytic cracker [10]. Ammonia decomposition also plays a critical role in medium-scale stationary power generation systems. In the UK, the Science and Technology Facilities Council (STFC), in collaboration with Siemens, Ecuity, and Engie, evaluated both centralized and distributed cracking approaches and designed a cracker capable of producing 200 kg of hydrogen per day [11]. Similarly, in China, several new energy companies have developed a demonstration project leveraging on-site ammonia decomposition for hydrogen production. This project utilizes advanced ammonia conversion technology developed by Professor Jiang's research team at Fuzhou University, supporting a zero-carbon emission energy community [12]. The decomposition of NH3 for H2 production was initially recognized as the reverse reaction of ammonia synthesis. However, this process faces a significant thermodynamic energy barrier, making the operating temperature during the decomposition reaction as high as 700 °C [13–15]. To overcome the challenge of high energy consumption, the development of highly efficient catalysts with excellent stability and low cost is critical for advancing NH3 decomposition technology and promoting the growth of a sustainable hydrogen economy [16]. Currently, Ru-based catalysts demonstrate the superior catalytic activity at low temperatures, but high cost hinders their widespread application [17,18]. As alternatives, transition metals such as Ni or Co have been extensive studied due to their lower cost and potential for activity enhancement, but also possess challenges such as structural sensitivity, susceptibility to oxidative sintering, and excessive N binding to active Ni sites [15]. Therefore, research efforts have focused on optimizing Ni-based catalysts by improving metal loading, tuning electronegativity, enhancing dispersion, and controlling particle size to maximize active site accessibility [19]. Various metal oxide supports, including SiO2, MgO, La2O3, CeO2, Y2O3, and Al2O3 have been utilized for Ni-based catalysts preparation [19–27]. Among these oxide support, CeO2 has attract considerable attention due to its high oxygen storage capacity, reversible Ce4+/Ce3+ redox cycling, abundant surface defects and tunable metal-support interactions [28]. Besides, the formation of oxygen vacancy and the Ce4+→Ce3+ transition facilitate electron transfer from CeO2 support to Ni surface, promoting the associative desorption of N adatoms and accelerating the catalytic reaction rate [24,29]. Despite these advances, the catalytic activity of Ni/CeO2-based catalysts still requires further optimization. Research indicates that when the Ni loading amount on CeO2 exceeds 10 %, nickel particles tend to agglomerate, resulting in a poor availability of active nickel sites [24]. Besides, pure ceria has only a limited number of oxygen defects and often shows severe agglomeration of crystalline domains because of its instability at high temperatures [30]. These factors will lead to the deactivation of Ni/CeO2 catalysts at elevated temperatures. Therefore, optimizing the support properties to enhance strong metal-support interaction (SMSI), inhibit the sintering of Ni nanoparticles, and enhance the thermal stability, oxygen vacancy density, and redox properties of CeO2 is currently the focus of research. Hence, recent studies have focused on support modification and promoter incorporation. For instance, Sima et al. [19] introduced Al3+ as a secondary dopant to increase the CeO2 surface oxygen vacancies and facilitate electron transfer. The synthesize Ni/AlCe0.8Zr0.2O2 catalyst exhibited superior ammonia decomposition activity, achieving complete conversion at 580 °C. Similarly, Zhou et al. [31] demonstrated that adding BN to Ni/CeO2 enhanced Ni nanoparticle dispersion, increased oxygen vacancy concentration, elevated Ce3+ content, and strengthened electronic metal-support interaction [24]. These modifications facilitated NH₃ activation and N-atom desorption, significantly boosting catalytic efficiency. It has been reported that incorporating La3+ into CeO2 facilitates the formation of a solid solution, promoting the generation of oxygen vacancies and Ce3+ species, which is conducive to the formation of electron-rich Ni species. Furthermore, La species can effectively inhibit the growth of active nickel nanoparticles and improve their dispersion. Therefore, La is commonly employed as a promoter to enhance the catalytic performance of Ni-based catalysts [32]. In this study, La2O3 was employed as a basic promoter to modify Ni/CeO2 catalysts due to its distinct electronic structure. The catalytic performance of La as promoter in Ni/CeO2 for ammonia decomposition was evaluated by preparing series Ni/Ce1-yLayOx catalysts. Characterization techniques such as TEM, BET, Raman, XPS, EPR, NH3-TPD and CO-Chem are employed to examine the effect of La3+ doping on the catalyst structure, oxygen vacancy and Ni distribution in Ni/Ce1-yLayOx catalysts. Moreover, reaction mechanism of ammonia decomposition was explored through in-situ DRIFTS and kinetic studies. This study introduced a rational design strategy for modulating the electronic states of active metals and optimizing reactant adsorption via constructing interface, offering a practical approach to the challenges of activity and stability in Ni-based catalysts. 2 Experimental section Details of catalyst preparation, characterization and ammonia decomposition tests were described in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization of the Ni/Ce1-yLayOx catalysts Fig. 1a shows the XRD patterns of Ce1-yLayOx supports. All samples exhibited characteristic diffraction peaks at 2 theta values of 28.5, 33.1, 47.5, 56.3, 59.1, 69.4, 76.7, 79.1 and 88.4°, corresponding to the (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331), (420) and (422) planes of CeO2 (PDF#34–0394), respectively. Upon La incorporation, the diffraction peaks of CeO2 shifted towards lower angles, along with gradual peak broadening and intensity reduction, which is probably due to the lattice expansion resulting from the substitution of Ce4+ ions (0.097 nm) by larger La3+ ionic (0.103 nm) in the fluorite lattice, confirming the successful formation of Ce1-yLayOx solid solutions [33,34]. Additionally, the diffraction peaks of La2O3 appeared at 27.3, 31.7 and 53.5° for Ce0.1La0.9Ox. Previous studies have demonstrated that at low La content (0 <y < 0.5), La primarily incorporates into the CeO2 lattice with partial surface segregation, whereas higher La content (0.6 <y < 0.9) lead to bulk-to-surface and mixed Ce-La phase formation [35,36]. A similar trend was observed in Ni/Ce0.1La0.9Ox catalyst, where the surface consistently exhibited higher La content compared to the bulk phase (Table S1). These observations suggested that La2O3 likely existed in the form of amorphous dispersion. Fig. 1b shows the XRD patterns of Ni/Ce1-yLayOx samples with 15 wt% Ni loading. The Ni/CeO2 sample exhibited distinct diffraction peaks at 44.5° and 51.8°, assignable to the (111) and (200) planes of Ni (PDF#87–0712), respectively. Importantly, the progressive weakening of Ni diffraction intensities with increasing La content indicated enhanced Ni dispersion on Ce1-yLayOx surface. This finding clearly demonstrated that La doping effectively promoted the dispersion of active Ni species, which was crucial for catalytic performance. The textural properties of Ni/Ce1-yLayOx samples were further investigated by N2 adsorption-desorption measurements (Fig. 1c, d). All samples displayed characteristic type IV isotherm with an H4-type hysteresis loop, typical of mesoporous structures with slit-shaped pores [37]. The specific surface area, pore size and volume were summarized in Table 1. Low content of La doping enhanced the specific surface area and pore volume of the Ni/Ce1-yLayOx samples, where Ni/Ce0.7La0.3Ox and Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox demonstrated higher specific surface areas (62 and 53 m2/g) and pore volumes (0.14 and 0.19 cm3/g) [38]. This higher specific surface area directly correlated with enhanced metallic dispersion, as evidenced by higher Ni dispersion values of 1.60 % and 1.90 % for Ni/Ce0.7La0.3Ox and Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox samples (Table 1). This indicated that more Ni sites were exposed on Ni/Ce0.7La0.3Ox and Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox surface, which would increase the density of accessible active sites for NH3 decomposition. Pore size distribution further confirmed the mesoporous nature of all Ni/Ce1-yLayOx samples, with main pore dimeters ranging from 2 to 20 nm and a sharp maximum centered at 2–4 nm. HRTEM technique was employed to investigate the nanostructure and size distribution of Ni nanoparticles in Ni/CeO2, Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox and Ni/Ce0.1La0.9Ox, as presented in Fig. 2. All samples exhibited distinct lattice spacing of 0.176 and 0.126 nm, attributed to (200) and (220) crystal plane of metallic Ni, respectively. Notably, the CeO2 (200) plane spacing expanded from 0.271 nm in CeO2 (Fig. S1) and Ni/CeO2 to 0.279 nm in Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox, providing evidence for successful formation of Ce1-yLayOx solid solution. Moreover, the appearance of lattice spacing with 0.282 nm in Ni/Ce0.1La0.9Ox (Fig. 2c) confirmed the existence of La2O3 (400) planes, consistent with previous XRD observations. The presence and size distribution of Ni particles were clearly visible in Fig. S2 and 2d-f. Statistical analysis of particle size distribution revealed a strong dependence of Ni nanoparticle size on the La/Ce molar ratio. The Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox showed superior dispersion with an average Ni particle size of 4.6 nm, significantly smaller than those observed on Ni/CeO2 (7.7 nm) and Ni/Ce0.1La0.9Ox (7.2 nm). This finding correlated well with the higher specific surface area and enhanced Ni dispersion. The superior dispersion can be attributed to the synergistic effect between the Ni-La metal that effectively prevented Ni nanoparticle agglomeration and migration [39]. However, excessive La loading resulted in surface precipitation of La2O3 species as evidence by HRTEM, which partially obscured active Ni sites and compromised metal accessibility [40]. EDS results in Fig. 2g-j confirmed the uniform dispersion of Ce and La elements, with Ni nanoparticles uniformly dispersed on the Ce0.5La0.5Ox support surface. Fig. 3a presents the H2-TPR profiles of NiO/Ce1-yLayOx samples, providing critical insights into the reducibility and metal-support interactions induced by La doping. The NiO/CeO2 sample exhibited a single reduction peak at 300 °C, which corresponded to the reduction of NiO species [35,37]. With the doping of La content, the main reduction peak shifted to higher temperature, and a distinct low-temperature reduction peak emerged. Specifically, well-defined low-temperature peaks at 225 °C and 234 °C were observed for Ni/Ce0.7La0.3Ox and Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox, respectively, corresponding to the reduction of highly dispersed, weakly interaction NiO nanoparticles [37,41]. This observation confirmed that moderated La doping facilitated the formation of well-dispersed NiO species. However, excessive La incorporation resulted in a substantially higher reduction temperature (380 °C), which could be attributed to the facts that the strong metal-support interaction induced by La incorporation, and the partial coverage of Ni species by La2O3 due to its intrinsic hydrophilic nature, creating a physical barrier for hydrogen access [42]. All these results demonstrated that La doping into CeO2 helps to form the well-dispersed NiO particles on the supports and modulated the strength of metal-support interactions. Ramam spectrum was measured to further investigate the structural properties of the Ni/Ce1-yLayOx samples, as shown in Fig. 3b. Two distinct peaks at 460 and 570 cm−1 were observed in all samples, corresponding to F2 g vibrational mode of the cubic fluorite CeO2 structure and the D-mode associated with defect-induced oxygen vacancy, respectively. As La dopped in CeO2, the F2 g peak exhibited a slight blue shift and its FWHM (Full Width at Half Maxima) increased, which was attributed to the lattice expansion, crystallite size reduction and oxygen vacancy presence induced by La doping [43]. The F2 g and D-mode peaks in Ni/Ce0.3La0.7Ox and Ni/Ce0.1La0.9Ox gradually diminished, which was due to the higher La content in the supports precipitating onto the catalyst surface, thereby covering the Ce1-yLayOx and oxygen vacancy on its surface. Quantitative analysis of oxygen vacancy concentrations, reflected by the intensity ratios of ID/IF2g revealed that Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox possessed higher ID/IF2g ratios of 0.8 among all Ni/Ce1-yLayOx. This suggested that the higher oxygen vacancy concentration on the surface, which strengthened metal-support interactions and promoted electron transfer from CeO2 to Ni active sites [22,29]. Furthermore, in order to more intuitively reveal the presence and strength of oxygen vacancies in the Ni/Ce1-yLayOx samples, EPR analysis was conducted and the results were shown in Fig. 3c. The symmetrical signal at g= 2.003 could be ascribed to oxygen vacancy. Apparently, Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox exhibited a stronger signal, indicating the higher oxygen vacancies content, which was well consistent Raman results. The XPS technique was conducted to investigate the surface elemental composition and electronic states of Ni, Ce, and La species in Ni/Ce1-yLayOx samples. Fig. 3d shows the deconvoluted Ce 3d XPS spectra, where the peaks denoted as u' (884.2 eV) and v' (903.5 eV) were associated with Ce3+ species, while the peaks labeled as u (882.1 eV), u'' (888.7 eV), u′'' (898.5 eV), v (900.8 eV), v'' (907.6 eV), v′'' (916.6 eV) corresponded to Ce4+ species [44]. The peak positions and peak areas for other catalysts are listed in Table S2, S3. Quantitative analysis revealed that La incorporation significantly enhanced Ce3+ content (Table 1), indicating that optimal La doping promoted the formation of oxygen vacancies through the charge compensation mechanism (Ce4+ + O2- → Ce3+ + Ov). Among all samples, the Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox exhibited the highest Ce3+ concentration, creating an electron-rich environment that promoted the electron transfer to Ni sites via oxygen vacancy and enhanced N2 desorption during ammonia decomposition [24]. The La 3d5/2 XPS spectra (Fig. 3e) of Ni/Ce1-yLayOx samples displayed spin-orbit splitting peaks. The splitting energy decreased from 4.7 eV (Ni/Ce0.9La0.1Ox) to 4.0 eV (Ni/Ce0.1La0.9Ox), approaching the characteristic value for La(OH)3. This may indicate La2O3 phases segregate to the surface and absorbs moisture from the air to form hydroxides at high La incorporation [45]. Significantly, Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox exhibited the highest La 3d5/2 binding energy, indicating the presence of abundant Lax+ species (x > 3) formed through strong Ce-O-La interfacial interactions [46]. The existence of Lax+ could modulate the electron density of surface Ni atoms through metal-support charge transfer, which is crucial for Ni-N cracking during NH3 decomposition [47]. The Ni 2p XPS spectra of Ni/Ce1-yLayOx samples was shown in Fig. 3f. For Ni/CeO2 samples, the characteristic peaks at 870.1, 871.4, 873.2 and 874.6 eV were assigned to Ni0 2p1/2, Niδ+ 2p1/2, Ni2+ 2p1/2 and Sat 2p1/2, respectively [46]. The presence of Ni2+ species predominantly originated from surface oxidation of Ni when exposed to ambient conditions, particularly in high Ni loading catalysts. With the doping of La, the Ni0, Ni2+, and Niδ+ characteristic peaks gradually shifted, and the binding energy of Ni0 in Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox was the lowest (869.9 eV), which was due to the Ce0.5La0.5Ox support with high Ce3+ and Ov content. Besides, this electron-rich structure likely forms a Ce-Ov-Ni interface on the catalyst surface and supplied more electrons to Ni0, which would increase the electron cloud density of Ni0, facilitated Ni-N bond breaking and accelerated N desorption and recombination on the metal surface [22,44,48]. The Ni0 content was calculated by Ni0/(Ni0+Ni2++Niδ+) and shown in Table 1. It was revealed that the Ni0 content was the highest in Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox samples, which was attributed to abundant Ce3+ species that help stabilize the Ni substance in its metallic Ni0 form and can effectively mitigate nickel oxidation [49]. High Ni0 content will provide more active sites, which enhanced NH3 decomposition. 3.2 Catalyst activity of NH3 decomposition The catalytic performance of the Ni/Ce1-yLayOx for ammonia decomposition were evaluated, and the result was shown in Fig. 4a. The temperature-dependent NH3 conversion was conducted from 220 to 620 °C with a rise step of 20 °C per data point. All catalysts exhibited enhanced activity with increasing temperature, with the highest catalytic performance observed for Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox, achieving 90.3 % NH3 conversion at 500 °C and GHSV of 9000 mL gcat −1 h−1. The catalytic performance followed the trend: Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox (90.3 %) > Ni/Ce0.7La0.3Ox (81.0 %) > Ni/Ce0.3La0.7Ox (79.7 %) > Ni/Ce0.1La0.9Ox (71.0 %) > Ni/Ce0.9La0.1Ox (48.9 %) > Ni/CeO2 (48.7 %). Notably, Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox demonstrated near-complete NH3 conversion (99.8 %) at 540 °C, highlighting its superior catalytic performance. In addition, the apparent activation energies (Ea) were calculated based on the Arrhenius plots, as illustrated in Fig. 4b. The activation energy (Ea) decreases in the following order: Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox (80 kJ/mol) < Ni/Ce0.9La0.1Ox (93 kJ/mol) < Ni/Ce0.7La0.3Ox (96 kJ/mol) < Ni/Ce0.3La0.7Ox (110 kJ/mol) < Ni/Ce0.1La0.9Ox (117 kJ/mol) < Ni/CeO2 (133 kJ/mol). The lowest Ea for Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox correlated well with its highest catalytic activity, achieving remarkable hydrogen production rate of 60.5 mmol−1 gNi −1 min−1 at 500 °C. These results highlighted the importance of metal-support interactions in facilitating NH3 decomposition, with the optimal La/Ce ratio in Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox significantly enhancing reaction kinetics. The long-term stability of Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox was examined through a continuous 50-hour reaction at 500 °C. As shown in Fig. 4c, the catalyst sustained 92 % NH3 conversion of its initial activity without significant deactivation, confirming its excellent durability. Post-reaction XRD analysis (Fig. 4d) revealed that the structure of Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox catalyst remained thermally stable, with no detectable Ni diffraction peaks, indicating that the preservation of well-dispersed Ni nanoparticles and no noticeable metal sintering occurred during the reaction. Furthermore, the cyclic stability of Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox was examined over five reaction cycles (220–620 °C) and shown in Fig. 4e. Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox exhibited no significant activity loss after five reaction cycles, demonstrating its robust structural stability. The influence of GHSV (9000–30000 mL gcat −1 h−1) on catalytic performance was also investigated (Fig. 4f). As expected, higher GHSV values resulted in lower NH3 conversion because of the shorter reactant residence time. While near-complete conversion was achieved at 540 °C when the GHSV was 9000 mL gcat −1 h−1, a higher temperature of 600 °C was required to achieve comparable conversion at 30000 mL gcat −1 h−1. The Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox catalyst demonstrated satisfactory stability and remarkable resistance to high GHSV conditions, highlighting its strong potential for practical application in NH3 decomposition. As evidenced by comparing with other reported Ni catalysts (Table S4), the prepared Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox catalyst exhibited superior catalytic performance under identical reaction conditions. This indicated the incorporation of La into CeO2 support significantly enhanced the catalytic performance for ammonia decomposition compared to pure CeO2 or other promoters such as Zr and Al. Furthermore, the high hydrogen production rate of Ni demonstrated that the metal utilization efficiency of Ni/Ce1-yLayOx catalyst had been significantly improved, suggesting considerable potential for its practical application as a candidate in hydrogen generation systems. 3.3 Reaction mechanism NH3-TPD technology was employed to investigate the adsorption and decomposition of NH3 on the catalyst surface. Before NH₃ adsorption, the Ni/Ce1-yLayOx catalysts were pre-reduced in H2/Ar atmosphere at 400 °C for 2 h. As shown in Fig. 5a, all samples exhibited distinct desorption peaks, indicating the adsorption of NH3 on their surfaces [50]. Moreover, the NH3 desorption peaks for Ni/Ce0.3La0.7Ox and Ni/Ce0.1La0.9Ox samples occurred at higher temperature, suggesting that NH3 was strongly adsorbed on their surfaces, which was primarily caused by the catalyst surface being covered with strongly basic La2O3. The Had and Nad atoms generated on the catalyst surface may recombine to NH3ad, leading to its release as NH3 g at elevated temperatures [51]. Besides, the maximum NH3 desorption peak on Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox catalyst indicated that the catalyst exhibited high NH3 adsorption capacity, which may be attributed to the abundance of available oxygen defect sites on the catalyst surface [19]. In Fig. 5b, the onset temperature of N2 desorption was approximately 100–200 °C higher than that of NH3, indicating that the recombination and desorption of N species was more challenging, becoming the rate-determining step in the NH₃ decomposition process [24,52]. Among all the catalysts, the N2 desorption temperature on Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox catalyst was relatively low, and intensity of the desorption peak was relatively high. This indicated that the recombination desorption of N atoms occurred more readily on the Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox catalyst, which facilitated the NH3 decomposition reaction [22]. Combining the Raman and XPS result, the enhanced N2 desorption on Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox catalyst closely related to the high Ce3+ concentration and oxygen vacancies in the support, enriching the electrons of the surface Ni through electron transfer, exciting Ni-N* species and thus promoting N2 desorption. To further elucidate the NH3 decomposition mechanism on the catalyst surface, in-situ DRIFTS measurements were conducted, and the spectra of NH3 adsorption on Ni/Ce1-yLayOx over the temperature range of 50–400 °C were shown in Fig. 6. The bands at 3500–3000 cm−1 and 2000–1000 cm−1 corresponded to the physically adsorbed NH3 or gaseous-phase NH3. The bands at 3333 cm−1 and 1624 cm−1 were attributed to NH₃ molecules adsorbed on Lewis acid sites [22]. The bands at 3800–3600 cm−1 are attributed to basic hydroxyl groups, which primarily interacted with NH3 molecules via hydrogen bonding [53]. The presence of these bands suggested strong chemisorption of NH3 on the catalyst. A pronounced decrease in the peak intensity at 1623 cm−1 was observed for the Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Oₓ and Ni/Ce0.3La0.7Ox catalysts, while only minor reductions were detected in the others. This suggests that NH₃ desorption or dehydrogenation occur more readily on Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Oₓ and Ni/Ce0.3La0.7Ox. Additionally, peaks at 1580–1517 cm−1 and 1500–1403 cm−1 were attributed to -NH2 species and -NH deformation mode, respectively, indicating that NH3 was effectively activated and dissociated into radical intermediates on the catalyst surface [22,54–57]. At 400 °C, the La content leads to divergent trends in the evolution of intermediate species. In the case of low La doping (y = 0–0.3), the peak intensity of -NH2 and -NH decreases. However, as the La content increased (y = 0.5–0.9), the intensity of the -NH2 peak first raised and then decreased at 400 °C. Considering the variation in peak intensity of NH3, the reduction of intermediate species peaks in Fig. 6a-c might stem from the relatively slow N-H bond cleavage rate in NH3, whereby -NH2 continued to be consumed as temperature increases (or time accumulated), likely through further dehydrogenation to form -NH or direct decomposition. The trend in the peak characteristics of the NH species was similar to the -NH2 species, indicating that the formation of NH was also restricted. Conversely, the initial increase of the -NH2 and -NH peaks in Fig. 6d-f suggested that N-H bond cleavage occurred in NH3. This change in peak intensity was most evident over the Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Oₓ catalyst. The strongest -NH2 peak observed on Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox indicated its superior ability to facilitate N-H bond cleavage. As the temperature increased, a greater amount of -NH2 species accumulated on the catalyst surface. This enhanced activity could be attributed to the electron-rich and highly dispersed active Ni sites, as well as the strong metal-support interaction in Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox, both of which promoted the breaking of N-H bonds [19,22,55]. The decrease in the -NH2 signal at 400 °C indicates that most of the -NH2 species further decompose into -NH, responding to the significantly enhanced -NH peak at 1492 cm−1 observed over Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox at the same temperature. Meanwhile, the characteristic -NH peak around 1425 cm−1 in Fig. 6d-f exhibited an initial increase followed by a decrease with rising temperature, suggesting that -NH underwent hydrogenolysis, ultimately forming N atoms. This indicated that the cleavage of N-H bonds likely followed the reaction pathway: NH3 → -NH3 → -NH → -N [56,58]. 4 Conclusion In summary, a series of Ni/Ce1-yLayOx catalysts with various La/Ce ratios were systematically investigated for NH3 decomposition. The Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox catalyst showed the best catalytic performance, achieving complete NH3 conversion at 540 °C (GHSV=9000 mL gcat −1 h−1) and 600 °C (GHSV = 30000 mL gcat −1 h−1) while maintaining excellent cycle stability and long-term stability at 500 °C over 50-hour period. Characterization studies revealed that the Ce0.5La0.5Ox support promoted high Ni dispersion with excellent anti-sintering properties, maximizing active site availability, and abundant oxygen vacancies that induced strong metal-support interaction, generating electron-rich Ni sites. Mechanistic studies through NH3-TPSR and in-situ DRIFTS collectively demonstrated that these oxygen vacancies enhanced NH3 adsorption while the electron-rich Ni facilitated N-H bond cleavage and N adatoms recombination, thereby accelerating the reaction rate. This work not only introduces a highly active, stable Ru-free catalyst but also elucidates the critical role of oxygen vacancy engineering in Ce-La mixed oxides for efficient ammonia decomposition, providing fundamental insights for designing cost-effective hydrogen production catalysts. coredata.dc:description: As a carbon-free hydrogen carrier, ammonia requires efficient decomposition catalysts to enable its practical use in hydrogen energy applications. In this study, a series of Ce1-yLayOx oxides with varying La/Ce molar ratios were synthesized via a citric acid method and utilized as supports for Ni-based NH3 decomposition catalysts. The La/Ce molar ratio significantly influenced the catalytic performance, with Ni/Ce0.5La0.5Ox exhibiting the highest catalytic activity, achieving nearly 100 % ammonia conversion at 540 ℃ (GHSV= 9000 mL gcat −1 h−1) and 600 ℃ (GHSV = 30000 mL gcat −1 h−1). Various characterizations demonstrated that optimal La/Ce ratio promoted uniform dispersion of Ni nanoparticles (4.6 nm), maximizing available active sites for NH3 adsorption. Moreover, the Ce0.5La0.5Ox support enriched the catalyst surface with high Ce3+ species and oxygen vacancies, facilitating electron transfer to Ni species. These electron-enriched Ni species significantly enhanced the cleavage of Ni-N bonds and facilitated the recombination of N adatoms, thereby boosting the overall reaction rate. This work provided fundamental insights into the critical role of metal-support electron transfer in optimizing catalytic performance for efficient ammonia decomposition, offering valuable guidance for the design of advanced hydrogen production catalysts.
